description: From Middle English torment, from Old French torment, from Latin tormentum (“something operated by twisting”), from torquere (“to twist”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A catapult or other kind of war-engine.
Torture, originally as inflicted by an instrument of torture.
Any extreme pain, anguish or misery, either physical or mental.
examples: He was bitter from the torments of the divorce.

verbs.description: torment (third-person singular simple present torments, present participle tormenting, simple past and past participle tormented)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause severe suffering to (stronger than to vex but weaker than to torture.)
examples: The child tormented the flies by pulling their wings off.
